entry.title: SAP BTP: Creating Connections at Supply Chain Connect
entry.content:
There’s excitement building in the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) team, as we get ready for the SAP Connect event, which will run from 6-8 October in Las Vegas. Of course, SAP Connect is different this year, with five events offered in one location, where attendees can enjoy a conference experience focused on their own Line of Business. Three of my colleagues have already been busy publishing blogs about SAP BTP topics you’ll be able to find at the conference, ijoaquin on Spend Management, rnoia on HCM and joanneks focusing on technology topics. Not wishing to feel left out, I thought that I would share a blog that focuses on my area of interest, SAP BTP for Supply Chain.

In working with my SAP Supply Chain Management colleagues on topics for the Supply Chain Connect event, we’ve decided to focus on SAP BTP capabilities that go to the heart of a “connected” supply chain, where integration and automation are key to creating agility and resilience. It will be of little surprise therefore that it is these very two topics that will be featured in sessions at the event.

Creating Connections

Integration is key to creating connectivity across supply chain systems and processes, and as such I would like to invite you to join my colleague, Craig Stasila, in two sessions where he will take a look at how SAP Integration Suite might be able to help you create a more connected, and collaborative supply chain:

SCM1886: Optimize your supply chain processes with SAP BTP | 7 Oct, 12:00PM – 12:20PM

In this session Craig will discuss how SAP BTP can help to unlock the potential for creating additional business value across supply chain processes.

SCM2278: Connecting the dots: A collaborative integration workshop | 7 Oct, 3:30PM – 4:45PM

Here Craig will lead an interactive workshop designed to get you thinking about how systems link together and how to get the most out of your approaches to integration. I think you’ll enjoy this one, so don’t miss it!

Automate for Efficiency

Automation and extension are two technology capabilities that can have a dramatic and positive effect on the efficiency, accuracy and productivity of business processes, as you’ll see if you attend this session led by my colleague Loujein Mouammer:

SCM1891 - Reimagine supply chain processes with automation and custom extensions | Oct 8, 12:00PM – 12:20PM

Here Loujein will take you through a demonstration of how automation and extension can help improve operational processes and drive better business outcomes.

Build Your Own Connections with the SAP Team

If you are attending SAP Connect this year, then while I’m sure that you’ll enjoy the SAP BTP sessions delivered by Loujein and Craig, if you are curious to learn more, why not take the opportunity to connect directly with members of the SAP BTP team, and delve into the topics of Integration, Automation and Extensibility a little more deeply. You’ll find the team located at our demo stations on the show floor, and I know that they’ll be excited to speak with you:

CROSS2318 | Connect the enterprise with SAP Integration Suite

CROSS2319 | Create AI agents and apps with SAP Build solutions

Of course if you’re unable to join the live event, then please consider joining the online event and experience SAP Connect Virtual from the comfort of your own office.

However you decide to attend, in-person or online, then I do hope you find SAP Connect to be a truly inspirational and rewarding experience. And of course – enjoy all the SAP BTP sessions!

entry.title: Finance Connect: Strategic Transformation, Not Just Applications
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

As finance leaders navigate an era where strategic agility isn't just advantageous (it's essential for survival), one statistic stands out: According to Gartner, 62% of CEOs have selected growth as their top business priority for 2024-2025, marking the highest level since 2014.

This surge in focus on growth presents both unprecedented opportunities and fundamental challenges: How do you transform finance from a reactive reporting function into a strategic growth engine that powers real-time decision-making across the enterprise?

For part 3 of this blog series on SAP Connect 2025, I’m sharing my list of must-attend sessions at SAP Finance Connect 2025. These sessions offer not just technological solutions but a strategic framework that aligns financial operations with growth imperatives for finance leaders and finance technology professionals.

If this is the first time you're hearing about SAP Connect 2025, read this blog first.

 

Flourishing Finance Function

Your organization has ambitious growth targets. Your CEO is pushing for expansion into new markets, product innovation, and operational scaling, adding responsibilities beyond finance to the office of CFO. Yet, when it comes to providing the financial processes and insights needed to fuel these initiatives, your finance team is still wrestling with:

  • Fragmented financial data scattered across multiple systems and departments
  • Manual reconciliation processes that delay critical decision-making
  • Disconnected planning cycles that can't adapt quickly to market changes
  • Limited visibility into real-time performance across business units

The path begins with understanding how connected finance can specifically support your organization's growth priorities.

The need to create a connected financial ecosystem that integrates, extends, and automates your finance solutions and processes can be met with SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP will strengthen your existing (and sometimes reactive) finance processes, transforming them into a proactive strategy that enables your finance function to flourish. Check out sap.com/btp-for-finance page for more in-depth information on how SAP BTP helps deliver better and more efficient Finance processes.

Here are my three must-attend sessions at Finance Connect that will expand how you think about finance technology possibilities:

 

Your must-attend sessions at Finance Connect

Scenario 1: Finance Closing

Your challenge: The Finance function needs to take the driver’s seat in leading the organization to be proactive in responding to changing requirements and strategies. But when it comes to financial close, it’s still a chaotic and manual process with many versions of documents and reviews.  Read about the full use case here.

The Solution: Explore Process Automation with SAP Build to streamline repeated processes. Eliminating manual tasks frees up your employees’ time, allowing them to focus on strategy and other important activities.

Business Impact: By automating and streamlining repetitive financial closing processes such as data entry and data collection, invoices can be processed 50% faster, with a 55% faster month-end close time.

If this is you, be sure to add this session to your agenda:

A fast close with SAP Advanced Financial Closing and SAP BTP | FIN1909

Wednesday Oct 8 | 11:15 AM – 12:00 PM PDT

 

Scenario 2: Enterprise Performance Management

Your challenge: Your team hopes to drive coordinated business transformation through enterprise performance management. But with multiple ERP and EPM applications, the execution of holistic performance management still struggles with fragmented systems that prevent effective forecasting and strategic alignment across the enterprise.

The Solution: Enterprise performance management technology should integrate easily with existing systems like financial consolidation and group reporting. Discover how SAP Integration Suite connects enterprise systems to streamline data availability, while SAP Build automates processes, enabling AI to deliver more accurate predictions.

Business Impact: In their session FIN2330, PwC shares how they were able to shorten close cycles and improve data accuracy in enterprise performance management.

If this is you, be sure to add these sessions to your agenda:

The EPM evolution: SAP EPM across the value chain | FIN2152

Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:00 AM – 11:20 AM PDT

Driving Financial Agility — PwC’s In-House EPM Transformation with Group Reporting | FIN2330

Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:15 PM – 4:00 PM PDT

 

 

Register Now: Start Your Strategic Finance Growth Journey

The goal is to create an intelligent financial nervous system that connects every aspect of your financial operations to drive outcomes. With SAP Business Technology Platform, your finance team can transform how your organization thinks, plans, and executes on growth opportunities.

Register now for Finance Connect 2025 to gain invaluable knowledge, discover SAP Business Technology Platform’s finance use cases, and join a community of organizations turning growth ambitions into a connected reality. Take the first steps to transform your financial operations into a strategic transformation advantage.

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Build – Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q3, we delivered several innovations across AI-powered development, ABAP project creation, modernized SAPUI5 and advanced mobile capabilities. SAP Build also reached a significant milestone with the introduction of MCP servers, allowing developers to boost productivity further with AI agents. 

Check these out in our Top 10 Release Highlights from Q3 2025! 

AI-powered development

1. Empowering developers with MCP Tools for SAP Build 

Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers are now available for the following technologies: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori. This is a huge step forward for developers working with popular IDEs and coding assistants like GitHub Copilot, Cursor and more. With these MCP servers, we’re now providing a comprehensive set of tools designed to optimize your development workflow across various SAP technologies.

Learn more in the blog post.

2. SAP HANA Cloud SQL Statement Generation in Joule

Directly in SAP Build Code, the Joule panel now offers the new command /hana-sql-gen, which enables the generation of SQL statements from natural language directly in the panel. The generated statements can be reviewed and refined in the Joule panel. Suitable SQL statements can be either copied to a SQL console or directly executed inside the Joule panel after selecting a database connection on which to run the statement.

3. Expanded AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone continues to expand its AI capabilities, bringing new built-in features to an intelligent workspace with accelerated decision-making and improved employee experiences:

  • Integration of Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition: By bringing Joule into SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, users can now enjoy the power of Joule within their digital workplace. This eliminates the hassle of system-hopping, reduces time wasted on searching for information, and allows employees to focus on what is important. (Note: Available in early October)
  • AI-powered text and comment generation: This enables employees to quickly create, summarize, and engage with workplace content. For example, project managers can generate project status updates in minutes, ensuring their team members stay aligned.

Learn more in the blog post.

Enhanced App Development & Automation

4. Availability of SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed 

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. This means app developers can test their UI code for compliance to SAPUI5 best practices. This helps to future-proof an SAP Fiori app for future SAPUI5 versions and work on deprecated/outdated code. Developers can also provide feedback to the UI5 team.

Learn more in the blog post.

5. Create full-stack ABAP projects in SAP Build

You can now create full-stack ABAP projects or open an existing ABAP CSN as a project in SAP Build. You can also model your application using the CDS Graphical Modeler and generate ABAP development objects. By leveraging high productivity tools, this significantly accelerates time-to-market, improves collaboration and provides a standardized, compliant approach to building extensions.

Learn more in the Help Portal. ..And stay tuned! We’ll share more about this topic at SAP TechEd 2025.

6. Maintenance project for released process automation projects

For process automation, we’ve introduced the ability to create dedicated project versions based on an existing released version. This allows process owners to maintain parallel editable versions while keeping the latest version in place, enabling teams to focus on solving a problem without redoing everything from scratch.

Learn more in the Help Portal.

7. Outbox functionality for tasks in SAP Task Center

SAP Task Center, which provides a seamless user experience for accessing open tasks, now lets you view completed tasks in an outbox. This provides a complete view of historical data while reducing support requests and efforts around process automation instances.

New innovations for mobile

8. UI enhancements available for mobile development

The latest release of SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is now available to customers, bringing with it multiple enhancements for UI creation. Developers can add a date range to their calendar controls, enable a read-only state, add required fields to forms, and much more.

Learn more in the latest blog post.

9. Support for new site experience in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition 

Employees accessing their workspace content via SAP Mobile Start can now enjoy a new view mode with a more flexible structuring of content. They can quickly view workspace updates, company news or project dashboards, making it easier to organize and consume information in a personalized way. (Note: Available in early October)

 

10. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

As the native mobile entry point to all SAP business apps and content, SAP Mobile Start has released several new innovations that simplify employee tasks and optimize their user experience:

  • SAP Document AI integration: Allows users to upload documents and photos for automated processing. This streamlines document handling, cuts down manual work and ensures data accuracy throughout operations.
  • Enhanced push notifications with more detailed information: Load and display context-specific details directly in the push notification, providing more meaningful and informative messages.
  • Simplified onboarding via deep link: IT teams can invite users to onboard to SAP Mobile Start via an email or message and provide a deep link that the users can use to initiate a simplified onboarding process.
  • Top news on start screen: Shows the most important news in a larger format on top of the Start screen.

Learn more in the latest blog post and Help Portal.

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What’s New in SAP Build Webinar on October 8th as we dive deeper into MCP servers in CAP, SAP Mobile Start innovations, and much more!

entry.title: Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP

Disclaimer: This article was inspired by SAP's work on modern cloud development, particularly the blog "How SAP's ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App simplifies multi-tenant side-by-side extensions," and is intended to explore these critical architectural topics further.

SAP is undergoing its largest transformation in decades—moving from on-premise monoliths to cloud-native architecture. Products like Datasphere, Analytics Cloud, and Business Data Cloud exist only in the cloud. Yet despite this fundamental shift, most software vendors still treat SAP like it’s 2010.

Let me explain why this gap is a massive opportunity for disruption—and why mastering the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is much harder than the marketing suggests.

The Architectural Divide: From Monolith to Node

To understand the BTP challenge, we must first recognize the dramatic shift in enterprise architecture.

The Old World: SAP as the Center of Gravity

For decades, SAP ECC was the undisputed heart of enterprise data. Every system pointed inward. CRM, warehouse management, custom applications—everything fed data into one central, tightly coupled system.

External Systems⟶SAP ECC Monolith⟶Single Source of Truth

This architecture made building SAP-integrated products deceptively straightforward:

  • Write ABAP code directly inside the SAP system.

  • Deploy via Transport Requests.

  • Access everything natively (tables, function modules, full transaction control).

I've seen incredibly sophisticated, high-performance solutions built entirely in ABAP. But notice this: many of these established ABAP vendors are slow to build cloud-native versions on BTP. This hesitation tells you something profound about the real challenges involved.

The New Reality: S/4HANA as Just Another Node

In today's distributed architecture, S/4HANA is simply one system among many. It sits alongside Salesforce, Workday, custom applications, and SAP’s own cloud products—all communicating through SAP BTP as the critical integration, extension, and application layer.

This fundamental change means you can no longer rely on deep, internal access to the core. It forces a complete overhaul of how you design and build SaaS products for the SAP ecosystem.

The BTP Reality: Why It's Harder Than It Looks

The core challenge lies in bridging the gap between the ABAP world's capabilities and the modern cloud platform’s constraints.

The ABAP Advantage (What You Lose)

When you build directly in ABAP (on-premise), you gain:

  • Direct access to all SAP objects and processes.

  • Standardized integration patterns (BAPIs, Function Modules).

  • Full transactional control and deep customization hooks.

  • 30+ years of accumulated frameworks and access methods.

The BTP Reality (What You Are Limited To)

On BTP, you are limited to officially sanctioned external access methods:

  1. APIs (REST, OData) – when they exist and are complete.

  2. RFC Calls/Web Services – (The "legacy" or "sidecar" approach).

  3. Custom ABAP Extensions – (The fallback when APIs fail).

The Technical Truth: Many older, niche, or newly migrated SAP modules do not have complete API coverage for every critical workflow step. This is not a criticism of SAP; it's the reality of a massive platform in transition. Building true SaaS products on BTP requires mapping your entire solution against the SAP API Business Hub before writing any code.

The Compelling Reason to Build SaaS on BTP

Despite the integration complexity, the strategic advantages of BTP are too significant for modern vendors to ignore. BTP is the enforcement mechanism for SAP's Clean Core strategy.

Strategic AdvantageWhy it Matters
1. Leverage SAP Objects Without Core ModificationUse SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to extend key SAP objects (Business Partners, Sales Orders, Materials) with custom fields and logic. This ensures your solution aligns with the Clean Core approach.
2. Instant User Management and SecurityIntegrate with BTP's XSUAA service. You instantly inherit customer's users, SSO integration, saving months of development and operational overhead on identity management.
3. Customer-Specific Extensions via MultitenancyShip one product while allowing customer-specific configurations and extensions. BTP's native multitenancy handles the data and configuration isolation, dramatically lowering codebase maintenance costs compared to the old world of branched ABAP code.
4. Modern Deployment and OperationsDeploy globally without hardware investment. Scale automatically based on demand. Use modern DevOps practices and CI/CD pipelines to update all customers simultaneously—a logistical nightmare with on-premise solutions.
 

Two Strategic Approaches to BTP SaaS

Your product's architecture should align with its core purpose:

Approach 1: Extend SAP Objects

Your product becomes a natural, value-add extension of core SAP functionality, leveraging the data models customers already use and understand.

  • Best for: Solutions that enhance existing SAP processes (advanced analytics, specialized compliance requirements, industry-specific workflows).

  • Technical Focus: Heavy reliance on CAP/RAP to extend standard entities and leverage the existing SAP transactional context.

Approach 2: Build Independent with SAP Integration (Loosely Coupled)

Create your own data model using modern frameworks (CAP/Node.js, Java) and integrate with SAP only as needed for master data and transactional exchange.

  • Best for: Products that could exist standalone but gain significant value from SAP integration (planning tools, specialized industry solutions, asset management).

  • Technical Focus: Strong emphasis on the SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh for asynchronous, reliable communication.

The Common Pitfalls I've Observed

Architectural success on BTP is often defined by avoiding these common traps:

1. The API Gap Surprise

Teams design beautiful cloud-native architecture assuming APIs exist for everything. When they discover a critical workflow is missing an API, they are forced to write custom ABAP in the S/4HANA core to create a needed OData service.

  • The Lesson: This creates a Custom ABAP Sidecar—it defeats the purpose of the BTP-native, Clean Core approach for that use case, complicating deployment and creating system-specific dependencies. Map your integration requirements against actual API availability before committing to architecture.

2. The Custom Integration Trap

A company builds its first SAP integration for Customer A, which takes six months. Customer B has different middleware, a different S/4HANA version, and unique customizations. Three years later, the company has five customers but five completely different integrations with no reusable product.

  • The Lesson: Design for product reusability from day one. Use BTP as the standard integration hub for all customers. Your product should treat the S/4HANA backend as an interchangeable service, not a monolithic dependency.

3. The Deployment Complexity

The product itself might be excellent, but if every customer implementation requires weeks of external SAP consulting to set up roles, connect services, and configure the integration, the deployment model doesn't scale economically.

  • The Lesson: Design your solution to be simple. Aim for a solution that can be deployed and configured by the customer’s existing SAP team in days, not months, using automated scripts and minimal manual steps.

My Strategic Focus

My focus is clear: to master the architecture required to build and commercialize a CAP template SaaS solution. By leveraging the best practices of the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and designing for native multitenancy, I aim to provide a production-ready, clean-core blueprint that accelerates the time-to-market for modern SAP solutions. This is the strategic direction for dominating the next era of the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Document AI to bring intelligent document processing into a classroom
entry.content:
Dear SAP University Alliances Community!

We would like to introduce you one of the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) services – SAP Document AI – and suggest a scenario how to introduce it to your students.

What is SAP Document AI?

SAP Document AI is an intelligent service that applies advanced machine learning to understand, classify, and process documents with high accuracy. Whether in research, classroom activities, or student projects, it provides a practical way to explore cutting-edge AI applications.

Key Features include:

  • Document Classification: Automatically categorizes documents by content.
  • Information Extraction: Accurately identifies and extracts fields, text, and tables.
  • Deep Learning Models: Ensures reliable performance through advanced algorithms.
  • Custom Training: Enables adaptation with your own datasets for specialized use cases.

Why It Matters for Academia

SAP Document AI is relevant across a wide range of academic disciplines:

  • Computer Science & Engineering: Perfect for hands-on projects in AI and machine learning.
  • Business & Management: Offers insights into automation, process optimization, and information management.
  • Legal Studies: Simplifies contract review and document analysis.
  • Healthcare & Life Sciences: Supports efficient processing of patient records and clinical trial data.

By integrating SAP Document AI into teaching and research, educators can bridge the gap between theory and real-world applications.

Bringing SAP Document AI in the educational process

One of the advantages is that SAP Document AI is its availability through the SAP BTP free trial. This allows students and educators to explore the service directly with no barriers and thus easily experiment with real scenarios, and develop skills that are highly relevant to today’s digital economy.

Essential resources to kickstart mastering SAP Document AI include:

  • SAP Discovery Center service page: overview, capabilities, and onboarding 
  • SAP Help Portal: SAP BTP Document AI 
  • API Business Hub: specs and try-outs 

Hands-On Learning Opportunities

The best way to understand SAP Document AI is to try it out. These tutorials and technology blogpost will help you get started step by step in just a little over one hour:

  • Create a Free SAP BTP Trial Account – suggested duration 15-20 minutes  
  • Use Trial to Set Up Account for SAP Document AI and Go to Application – suggested duration 5-10 minutes 
  • Use Trial to Extract Information from Standard Documents with Generative AI and SAP Document AI – suggested duration 25-30 minutes   
  • Processing a Pokémon Card in 90 Seconds with SAP Document AI 

Recommended classroom flow based on the listed above SAP Document AI tutorials:

  • Session 1: Trial account setup and service activation (refer to the turtorial "Create a Free SAP BTP Trial Account”, and then “Use Trial to Set Up Account for SAP Document AI and Go to Application”).
  • Session 2: Explore the web app, upload sample invoices/POs, and review extraction results with human-in-the-loop validation.
  • Session 3: Use generative AI to configure extraction for custom document types (refer to the tutorial “Extract Information from Custom Documents”). Compare outcomes across formats and languages.
  • Session 4: Run the “Pokémon Card in 90 Seconds” challenge to demonstrate rapid, end-to-end extraction. Debrief on human-in-the-loop UX and data quality.
  • Optional: Connect extraction results to a simple workflow or app (for example, with SAP Build Process Automation, please refer to the respective Sandbox offering from UCC Magdeburg) for an end-to-end process demo.

Ideas for Assignments and Projects

  • Measure quality of processed documents: Benchmark precision across document templates and languages. Propose prompt or configuration tweaks to improve results.
  • Design workflows: Build an approval flow that routes low-confidence extractions to human review.
  • Time-and-cost analysis: Compare manual vs. automated processing time and estimate business value in a mini case study.
  • Cross-discipline collaboration: Pair business students (process design) with computer science students (API integration) to deliver a working prototype.

Final Thoughts on SAP Document AI

SAP Document AI offers a unique opportunity to combine academic learning with industry-level technology. Whether you’re a student working on your first AI project, or an educator designing courses that reflect the future of work, this tool can make a real difference. Stay tuned for the update in the SAP Universiry Competence Center Magdeburg content on SAP S/4HANA, when a SAP Document AI case will become part of the Global Bike Curricula.

We invite you to explore SAP Document AI, share your experiences, and join the discussion in the comments. Together, let’s bring innovation to the classroom!

Further Inspiration

Looking for ways to bring other SAP innovative technology in the classroom? Explore Academic Lessons by SAP University Alliances. These ready-to-use materials provide practical scenarios to integrate SAP technology into curricula and give students direct exposure to industry-relevant tools.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #5 in the Series
entry.content:
This is the final chapter in this blog series on the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I’ve described key features that offer significant benefits for your organization and can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

Although it can be difficult calculating the business value of migrating your database to the cloud, the expertise of independent organizations can be helpful. A recent IDC study[1]  used a specialized business value methodology to assess the benefits of SAP HANA Cloud delivered to participating organizations. IDC concluded that the benefits were worth an annual average of US$13.7 million per organization and that the database enabled a 35% three-year reduction in total cost of ownership.

If you don’t have time to read this report, I encourage you to complete your own organization assessment using our free tool. In less than five minutes, you’ll receive useful insights that can help you decide your next steps.

 

Let’s consider two more features of SAP HANA Cloud that can help you realize significant business value: comprehensive security and a complete application development ecosystem.

Comprehensive security

Protecting your data and helping ensure compliance are top concerns for every organization. As business operations and workforces become more distributed, the need to provide secure data access from anywhere in the world intensifies.

SAP HANA Cloud offers robust security features that cover critical data protection areas, including authentication, authorization, user management, data masking, anonymization, and encryption. Because these features are built into the database, you have little or no need for third-party security tools. These capabilities also reduce the administrative effort needed to protect data.

Support for multiple security certifications and standards, such as ISO (International Organization for Standardization) and SOC (Standard Occupational Classification), helps ensure regulatory compliance. Configurable audit policies streamline compliance activities while helping protect your business and your customers. Automated updates to libraries and applications also boost security.

These features help make it faster and simpler to meet your security goals. According to the IDC report, the security teams of organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud increased efficiency by 19%. This benefit translates into an average annual business value of $183,016 per organization.

One study participant from the agriculture industry cited the database security standards and policies of SAP HANA Cloud, considering it an extra protective layer to reinforce security. “If we had an on-premises database, we’d lack this added protection,” said the interviewee. “The entire platform has policies that prevent mistakes. For instance, SAP now requires updates to libraries and applications for security reasons. These requirements from SAP keep us updated and secure.”

Another participant from the healthcare industry viewed the advanced protection as a financial advantage. “SAP HANA Cloud is a much more secure system that makes data more accessible and applications perform faster,” he said. “This has helped us meet our customers’ needs much better and has improved our revenue by about five percent.”

A complete application development ecosystem

Time and resources are tight for your development teams. Demand from business users has never been higher, new use cases are emerging, and the need for different developer skill sets seems to continually grow.

SAP HANA Cloud can help address these challenges with an integrated development ecosystem based on SAP Build solutions. SAP Build offers a comprehensive group of tools that support the full spectrum of no-code/low-code, pro-code, and generative AI development approaches. With SAP Build and SAP HANA Cloud, you can support developers at any skill level with the right tools.

Developers can build intelligent applications that use generative AI and harness their expertise and data. Applications built on SAP HANA Cloud can use intelligent algorithms to process large volumes of data and provide actionable recommendations. SAP HANA Cloud also includes machine learning libraries that help developers build sophisticated analytics applications that augment user expertise. By incorporating AI-driven insights, these applications help you anticipate future trends and predict behaviors, make business decisions faster, and improve business performance.

The IDC report found that these application development capabilities deliver quantifiable business value. IDC estimates that development team productivity spiked by 30% in the surveyed organizations, creating staff time savings of $361,519 per organization.  

SAP HANA Cloud features, such as information libraries, combined with faster performance and easier integrations, helped developers build more complex applications such as those using machine learning and AI. Overall, participants developed or deployed 154% more features and applications annually than they could without SAP HANA Cloud.

One study participant explained the impact of this value on the development team. “SAP HANA Cloud provides developers with more seamless integrations, and it is easy to use,” the interviewee explained. “They spend less time writing code because they can reuse code and use the libraries.”

 

Explore additional SAP HANA Cloud resources

As we’ve seen in this , the advanced features of SAP HANA Cloud offer significant value for organizations like yours. To help you make your business case for SAP HANA Cloud, check out the following resources:

  • What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 
  • Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.
  • Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.
  • Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1] “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Secure Your Digital Journey with SAP CIAM
entry.content:
Secure Your Digital Journey with SAP CIAM 

Over the years, working in customer experience and digital technologies, I have witnessed the rapid evolution of both customers and the infrastructure needed to serve them.  When you consider the “customer,” the need to understand who they are has become a central focus of the user experience. The world of digital identity has continuously adapted. Social logins once felt like the future—now, passwordless or passkey authentication is a requirement. Data privacy has shifted from an afterthought to a boardroom priority, largely driven by regulations like GDPR, CCPA, and others. What used to be considered "good enough" security no longer suffices, as becoming the subject of a data breach headline is a risk no company can afford.. 

Even my daughter now warns me not to share her identity online, as I don’t have her consent—proof that awareness of digital risks is becoming second nature to the next generation. In this new era, trust isn't a nice-to-have; it’s the foundation of every customer interaction. 

That’s why Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) is a critical part of any modern digital strategy and future-forward IT landscape. When organizations get digital identity right, they unlock more than just security—they create better, more trusted customer experiences at every touchpoint. 

 

Bridge the Gap Between Experience and Trust 

In today's digital-first landscape, businesses must navigate the challenge of delivering seamless customer experiences while ensuring robust data protection—a balance that is crucial for building trust with increasingly privacy-conscious consumers. However, many organizations are stuck navigating data silos, which fragment customer insights and prevent a unified understanding of their audience.  

SAP CIAM offers a comprehensive solution to these challenges by unifying data management, enhancing security frameworks, and simplifying privacy compliance. It empowers businesses to protect against threats, manage identities efficiently, and offer personalized user experiences that foster customer loyalty. 

SAP CIAM overcomes the limitations of outdated systems and enables organizations to confidently: 

  1. Secure users 
  1. Reduce privacy concerns 
  1. Scale efficiently 

 

  1. Secure Users and Safeguard Data  

Concerned about data breaches? SAP CIAM is engineered to protect your customer data and minimize security risks, building trust between you and your customers. By prioritizing robust threat detection and protection, this solution ensures your business remains secure, fostering loyalty and reinforcing customer confidence in sharing their data.   

  • Access real-time password suggestions 
  • Utilize built-in screen sets for password updates 
  • Generate one-time passwords 
  • Integrate with external identity services 
  • Enable biometric sign-in for secure login 
  • Harness AI risk-based authentication 

 

For a deeper look at how SAP CIAM addresses today’s evolving security landscape, join us at SAP TechEd on November 6 for a dedicated CIAM security session. Register here to secure your spot and learn more. 

 

  1. Reduce Privacy Compliance Risk 

Keeping up with evolving privacy regulations can be daunting. SAP CIAM simplifies these challenges through efficient consent management capabilities, enabling businesses to adhere to global standards like ISO, BSI, and SOC 2. With user-friendly self-service portals, SAP CIAM respects customer privacy while maintaining compliance—ultimately strengthening trusting relationships. 

  • Capture consent across all channels 
  • Customize for privacy policies and brand 
  • Configure single sign-on (SSO) 
  • Enable global access 

 

  1. Increase Efficiency at Scale 

Worried about system overload during peak times? SAP CIAM effortlessly manages traffic spikes, supporting billions of unique identities and transactions monthly. This capability allows businesses to capitalize on each opportunity without technical setbacks or undue stress on IT teams. With 347 million active users across 85 thousand sites, SAP CIAM is a proven solution for large-scale digital operations. 

  • Design and execute identity flows 
  • Duplicate site configurations and settings 
  • Offer OOTB, OIDC-compliant login experiences 
  • Create identity screens with drag-and-drop 

 

Elevate Your Identity Strategy with SAP CIAM 

SAP CIAM empowers businesses to bolster their security measures, ensure data privacy compliance, and efficiently scale their digital operations. Additionally, it offers pre-configured connectivity with over 60 SAP products, including SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP S/4HANA, SAP Customer Experience solutions, and SAP cloud ERP solutions, enhancing integration across your enterprise. 

Incorporating SAP CIAM into your digital strategy could be the next step toward elevating your business with enhanced security, data protection, and scalability.

entry.title: What’s new in Mobile development kit client 25.9
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I am happy to announce that a new release of the Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is now available for all SAP Build (and Mobile Services) customers. You can download it from the SAP Software Center, and also available on the community Download page.

The SAP Mobile Services Client has been updated to version 25.9.0 on both the Google Play Store and the Apple App Store.

SAP Mobile Development Kit enables developers and technical business users to build cross-platform mobile applications. It allows you to build your application once, in an integrated development environment (SAP Business Application Studio / VSCode extension) and run it natively on Mobile (Android & iOS).  

Below UI enhancements are available only on iOS and Android platforms:

  • Support Date Range Selection in Calendar Control
  • Support Event Indicators in Calendar Control
  • Support Read-Only State in FormCell Attachment Control
  • Support Attachment Limit in FormCell Attachment Control
  • Support Required Field Indicators for FormCell Controls
  • Introduce Additional Properties in Timeline Cell Control
  • Support Viewing Password-Protected PDFs in Native File Viewer (Android only)
  • Enable Nested Scrolling on SectionExtension (Android only)

Support Date Range Selection in Calendar Control 

MDK now supports date range selection in the Calendar Section control, in addition to single-date selection. The date range selection displays the calendar in a month-view format and allows multiple months to be shown. Users can scroll vertically through the calendar months. Use this option to enable the selection of a continuous date range.

  • The first date selected becomes the start date of the range.
  • The second date selected becomes the end date of the range.
//excerpt of an MDK page
{
    "Height": 0,
    "EventLoadRange": 1,
    "OnSelectedDateRangeChange": "/MDK2509/Rules/Calendar/OnSelectedDateRangeChange.js",
    "_Type": "Section.Type.Calendar",
    "_Name": "Calendar",
    "Header": {
        "_Type": "SectionCommon.Type.Header",
        "_Name": "SectionCommonTypeHeader0",
        "Caption": "Caption",
        "Items": [{
            "_Type": "SectionHeaderItem.Type.Label",
            "_Name": "SectionHeaderItemTypeLabel0",
            "Title": "Range Selection"
        }]
    },
    "CalendarType": "DateRange",
    "StartDayOfWeek": "Sun",
    "IsPersistentSelection": true
},

Additional Features:  

  • OnSelectedDateRangeChange event: This event is triggered when the selected date range is changed.
  • getSelectedDateRange / setSelectedDateRange APIs: These APIs allow you to get or set selected date range programmatically via CalendarProxy.

Platform Behavior

  • iOS:
    • To modify the selected range, tap any selected date within the range. That date becomes the new end date, and all later dates are deselected.
    • To clear the selection, tap outside the selected range anywhere in the calendar view.
  • Android:
    • Tapping any date—whether within or outside the selected range—will select that date.

Date Range Selection in Calendar Control on iOS and Android

For more information, refer to the Calendar documentation.

Support Event Indicators in Calendar Control

MDK now supports identifying special events or statuses directly on the calendar. This feature helps users to quickly spot important dates and plan more effectively. Indicators can have customizable appearances and can be assigned statically (via metadata) or dynamically (at runtime), providing an efficient way to manage and view calendar events.

//excerpt of an MDK page
 {
  "_Type": "Section.Type.Calendar",
  "_Name": "Calendar",
  "CalendarType": "Month",
  "StartDayOfWeek": "Sun",
  "IsPersistentSelection": true,
  "Height": 0,
  "EventLoadRange": 1,
  "Indicators": [{
    "_Name": "StartDateIndicator",
    "Icon": "sap-icon://begin",
    "Styles": {
      "Icon": "BlueIndicator"
    },
    "Title": "Start Date"
  }, {
    "_Name": "DueDateIndicator",
    "Icon": "sap-icon://project-definition-triangle-2",
    "Styles": {
      "Icon": "RedIndicator"
    },
    "Title": "Due Date"
  }],
  "Events": "/MDK2509/Rules/Calendar/GetEventData.js"
}

Event Indicator in Calendar Control on iOS and Android

 

For more information, refer to the Event Indicator documentation.

Support Read-Only State in FormCell Attachment Control 

MDK now supports restricting attachment management within a FormCell Attachment control. When disabled, the control automatically hides the Add button as well as the Remove (or delete) option for each attachment.

 

This behavior is controlled via the IsEditable property in the metadata, which accepts a boolean value.

"IsEditable": true

You can control this dynamically at runtime using the setEditable() and getEditable() APIs in a rule.

formcell.setEditable(true)
editable = formcell.getEditable()

Support Attachment Limit in FormCell Attachment Control

  • Maximum File Size: You can also configure the maximum file size (in MB) allowed for each attachment added to the FormCell Attachment control. If not specified, or set to a value less than or equal to 0, no file size limit is enforced.
//excerpt of an MDK page 
{
  "_Type": "Control.Type.FormCell.Attachment",
  "_Name": "InitialLimits",
  "IsEditable": true,
  "MaxAttachments": 2,
  "MaxFileSize": 1,
  "AttachmentActionType": ["AddPhoto", "TakePhoto", "SelectFile"],
  "AttachmentTitle": "Initial Values (%d)"
},​
  • Maximum Attachment Count: You can now configure FormCell Attachment control to restrict how many attachments a user can upload. Once the specified limit is reached, the control disables the Add button to prevent further uploads.
    In metadata, configure the maximum limit using the MaxAttachments property.
"MaxAttachments": 4​

Note:

  • If the property is not configured—or is set to zero or a negative value—no limit is enforced by default. 
  • Platform behavior: 
    • iOS: The limit is applied directly to the native file picker, which prevents additional file selection once the maximum is reached.
    • Android: The native file picker does not restrict selection. Users may select more files than allowed, but only the first N attachments (where N is the configured limit) are retained after confirmation. 

 

At runtime, you can set or query the limit using the APIs (setMaxAttachments and getMaxAttachments . 

attachment.setMaxAttachments(4);  
maxAttachments = attachment.getMaxAttachments();

Support Required Field Indicators  for FormCell Controls 

This feature allows developers to add a Mandatory Fields Indicator to FormCell controls, indicating that the field must be filled out.

Note: This feature does not enforce the user to fill out the form cell—it only provides visual indicator that the field is required.

By default, the indicator is a red asterisk (*) placed at the end of the caption. Developers can customize this indicator by specifying a different character in the metadata using the RequiredIndicator property.

  • Only a single character is allowed for customization.
  • If more than one character is defined, the system will revert to using the default indicator. 
  • Additionally, the appearance of the indicator can be styled through metadata.

//excerpt of an MDK page
{
   "Value": "Enter Date",
   "_Type": "Control.Type.FormCell.DatePicker",
   "_Name": "fcDatePicker",
   "RequiredIndicator": true,
   "Caption": "Date Picker",
   "Mode": "Datetime"
 },

The form cells that support this feature include:

  • Attachment Form Cell

  • DatePicker Form Cell
  • DurationPicker Form Cell
  • InlineSignatureCapture Form Cell
  • ListPicker Form Cell
  • Note Form Cell
  • SignatureCapture Form Cell
  • SimpleProperty Form Cell

For more information, see this  documentation.  

Introduce Additional Properties in Timeline Cell Control

With this release, MDK now supports displaying additional text properties—such as StatusText, SubstatusText, and Subattribute—on the right side of the timeline cell.

 

"StatusText": "Status1"
"SubstatusText": "Status2",
"Subattribute": "Subattribute",

For more information, see this  documentation.  

Support Viewing Password-Protected PDFs in Native File Viewer (Android only)

MDK now supports viewing password-protected PDF files in the native file viewer on Android.

Fiori Dialog box when opening a password protected PDF on Android

Enable Nested Scrolling on SectionExtension (Android only)

In case you're using a Section Extension control for a custom extension implementation and the height of the extension area cannot display the full content, you can use the new IsScrollable property in the Section Extension control to enable nested scrolling within the extension view.  The default setting is false.

entry.title: From Penalty to Power Play: Why Identity Management Is Key to Better Customer Experiences
entry.content:
A few weeks ago, a friend bought tickets to a hockey game and wanted to transfer them to me. Like many people, we went with the quickest workaround—she shared her login credentials so I could access the tickets. But what should have been a simple process turned into several days of password resets, missed messages, and back-and-forth. By the time I finally got into her account, the tickets were gone. She had attempted to transfer them during the delay, but amid the confusion and technical issues, I never actually received them. If I had been able to log in right away, I could have just downloaded them directly. But the access issues created confusion, and without any clear support from the platform, we ended up losing the tickets—and missing the game.

It was a simple plan that fell apart because of something as basic as account access.

This experience is a small example of a much larger issue in digital commerce: the friction that arises when identity management isn’t built with the customer in mind. It’s easy to overlook, but poor identity experiences lead directly to lost opportunities—not just for consumers, but for the businesses trying to reach them.

 

Identity Friction = Lost Revenue

In today’s commerce landscape, customer expectations are sky-high. If a login process is confusing, if an account is hard to access, or if personalization feels off—people walk away. And often, they don’t come back.

Poor identity experiences hurt businesses in more ways than one:

  • They interrupt the buying journey. Whether it’s a login loop, a forgotten password, or a complicated checkout flow, friction at these key points drives abandonment.
  • They block personalization. When customer data is fragmented across systems, it’s hard to deliver the tailored experiences that today’s buyers expect.
  • They erode trust. Without clear consent management and transparency, customers hesitate to share information—or stop engaging entirely.
  • They slow down growth. Outdated systems and homegrown solutions often can’t keep up with omnichannel strategies or evolving compliance needs.

For a deeper dive into how SAP CIAM can help reduce identity friction, join us at SAP TechEd on November 6 for a dedicated CIAM security session. Register here to secure your spot and learn more.

 

Where SAP CIAM + Commerce Cloud Make the Difference

Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) helps solve these challenges by making identity work for the customer—not against them. When integrated into your commerce ecosystem, CIAM doesn't just handle sign-ins—it actively supports better customer relationships and business outcomes.

Here’s how:

  • It reduces friction at every stage—from anonymous browsing to account creation to repeat purchases. The experience becomes smoother, simpler, and more secure.
  • It improves conversion by enabling personalized, real-time engagement without relying on clunky data handoffs or third-party cookies.
  • It builds trust by giving customers control over their data, preferences, and permissions—while helping businesses stay compliant across regions.
  • It supports scale by integrating identity across every digital touchpoint, enabling consistent experiences on web, mobile, in-store, and beyond.

In short, CIAM allows businesses to move away from fragmented, frustrating interactions and toward a unified customer experience that feels intuitive, safe, and relevant—every time. To hear firsthand how SAP customers are achieving this with SAP CIAM and Commerce Cloud, join us at SAP Connect in Las Vegas on October 8. Register here to attend.

 

The Takeaway

In commerce, moments of friction are more than just annoyances—they’re missed opportunities. Whether it’s lost hockey tickets or lost revenue, the cause is often the same: a broken identity experience.

Modern CIAM, especially when combined with a powerful commerce platform, turns identity into an asset. It streamlines the journey, protects the user, and empowers businesses to engage with clarity and confidence.

And the best part? It just works—so your customers don’t have to.
